<p>Like many people, I&rsquo;ve been diving into Generative AI (GenAI) over the past 12 or so months and looking at how to use it in the sorts of solutions we can build. I&rsquo;m also the kind of tinkerer that is looking for how to use technology in weird and wonderful ways. So, I&rsquo;ve been looking at how to use GenAI in my smart home.</p> <p>Before we get into that part of the story, a little bit of context around something I was doing recently. For the better part of a year I&rsquo;ve had a daily notification that runs for our kids which tells them what they have on that day at school, whether it&rsquo;s their library day, they have sport, after school care, etc. This runs at 8.30am, which is just before we leave the house and, well, it&rsquo;s been a bit of a &ldquo;Pavlov&rsquo;s bell&rdquo; for them. They hear the notification and they know what&rsquo;s coming up that day and that it&rsquo;s time to be ready to leave.</p> <p>The thing is, this message is pretty static, I run a template that looks at a bunch of helpers setup in Home Assistant and then generates a message. It&rsquo;s a bit boring because it&rsquo;s very static, like &ldquo;<child name> here are your school reminders. It&rsquo;s sports day, don&rsquo;t forget your sports shoes. You have after school care today.&rdquo; It&rsquo;s the same generalised message, just plugging a few different variables in, so it solves the problem but it&rsquo;s not very interesting.</p> <h2 id="enter-genai">Enter GenAI <a class="header-link" href="#enter-genai"><svg height="22px" viewBox="0 0 24 24" width="22px" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M0 0h24v24H0z" fill="none"/><path d="M3.9 12c0-1.71 1.39-3.1 3.1-3.1h4V7H7c-2.76 0-5 2.24-5 5s2.24 5 5 5h4v-1.9H7c-1.71 0-3.1-1.39-3.1-3.1zM8 13h8v-2H8v2zm9-6h-4v1.9h4c1.71 0 3.1 1.39 3.1 3.1s-1.39 3.1-3.1 3.1h-4V17h4c2.76 0 5-2.24 5-5s-2.24-5-5-5z"/></svg></a></h2><p>After upgrading the hardware my Home Assistant instance runs on (from a Pi4 to a NUC), I have a bit more power to play with, so I had been running some Small Language Models (SLMs) on the NUC to see what I could do with them. The NUC itself is too underpowered to be used as a local GenAI server to back the Assistants part of Home Assistant (I tried, Phi3-mini doesn&rsquo;t have a large enough token cap for the system message, let alone a user message, and anything larger takes so long to response that it&rsquo;s completely impractical ü§£), but if it&rsquo;s running a SLM that is only serving responses on occasions, well that should be fine.</p> <h2 id="hello-ollama">Hello Ollama <a class="header-link" href="#hello-ollama"><svg height="22px" viewBox="0 0 24 24" width="22px" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M0 0h24v24H0z" fill="none"/><path d="M3.9 12c0-1.71 1.39-3.1 3.1-3.1h4V7H7c-2.76 0-5 2.24-5 5s2.24 5 5 5h4v-1.9H7c-1.71 0-3.1-1.39-3.1-3.1zM8 13h8v-2H8v2zm9-6h-4v1.9h4c1.71 0 3.1 1.39 3.1 3.1s-1.39 3.1-3.1 3.1h-4V17h4c2.76 0 5-2.24 5-5s-2.24-5-5-5z"/></svg></a></h2><p>The first thing we need to do is have a way in which we can run the SLM and get a response. I&rsquo;m going to be using <a href="https://ollama.com">Ollama</a>, as it&rsquo;s a nifty little tool for working with models like this, and it can be run either as a standalone executable, or as a Docker container. Follow their guide on how to get it running on whatever host you have (I&rsquo;m using Docker on my NUC).</p> <p>Next, we&rsquo;ll need to pick a model to use. Because I&rsquo;m running this on a NUC, I don&rsquo;t really have a GPU to play with, so I&rsquo;ve decided to go with a pretty small model, <a href="https://azure.microsoft.com/blog/introducing-phi-3-redefining-whats-possible-with-slms/">Phi3</a> using the <code>mini</code> variant of it, which is only about 2gb of disk size and has 3.82B parameters. It&rsquo;s not really that big, but given we&rsquo;re going to be CPU-bound for this, we&rsquo;ll have to make some tradeoffs (let&rsquo;s just say, I won&rsquo;t be running llama3.1:405b anytime soon üòÖ).</p> <p>With everything setup, I can hit ollama with a request:</p> <div class="highlight"><div style="background-color:#f0f3f3;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"> <table style="border-spacing:0;padding:0;margin:0;border:0;"><tr><td style="vertical-align:top;padding:0;margin:0;border:0;"> <pre tabindex="0" style="background-color:#f0f3f3;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code><span style="white-space:pre;-webkit-user-select:none;user-select:none;margin-right:0.4em;padding:0 0.4em 0 0.4em;color:#7f7f7f">1 </span></code></pre></td> <td style="vertical-align:top;padding:0;margin:0;border:0;;width:100%"> <pre tabindex="0" style="background-color:#f0f3f3;-moz-tab-size:4;-o-tab-size:4;tab-size:4;"><code class="language-bash" data-lang="bash"><span style="display:flex;"><span>curl -X POST -H <span style="color:#c30">&#34;Content-Type: application/json&#34;</span> -d <span style="color:#c30">&#39;{&#34;prompt&#34;: &#34;What should I tell the kids today?&#34;, &#34;model&#34;: &#34;phi3&#34;, &#34;stream&#34;: false}&#39;</span> http://ollama.local:11434/api/generate </span></span></code></pre></td></tr></table> </div> </div><p><em>Note: We set <code>stream: false</code> in the JSON payload to ensure we get the whole completion as a single response rather than a stream of responses. storing the response in a response variable, then using the <code>wait_for_trigger</code> action to wait until 8.30am before broadcasting the message. If the Ollama API call fails, we just skip that child&rsquo;s announcement. We also wait for the TTS service to finish before moving onto the next child&rsquo;s announcement.</p> <h3 id="example-run">Example Run <a class="header-link" href="#example-run"><svg height="22px" viewBox="0 0 24 24" width="22px" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M0 0h24v24H0z" fill="none"/><path d="M3.9 12c0-1.71 1.39-3.1 3.1-3.1h4V7H7c-2.76 0-5 2.24-5 5s2.24 5 5 5h4v-1.9H7c-1.71 0-3.1-1.39-3.1-3.1zM8 13h8v-2H8v2zm9-6h-4v1.9h4c1.71 0 3.1 1.39 3.1 3.1s-1.39 3.1-3.1 3.1h-4V17h4c2.76 0 5-2.24 5-5s-2.24-5-5-5z"/></svg></a></h3><p>Today, one of my kids didn&rsquo;t have any &ldquo;special&rdquo; activities at school, so the message that was sent to the SLM was:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>Create a friendly response that will announced over our house speakers in the morning to inform a child of their activities that they have today.
Keep it short, it should be announced in the space of about 1 minute.
The child&#39;s name is &#39;&lt;child&gt;&#39;, and the following is a description of what their day involves.
## Description
There are no special activities at school today. </code></pre><p>And the response back from Ollama was:</p> <pre tabindex="0"><code>Good morning &lt;child&gt;! It&#39;s time to get ready for another exciting day ahead. School starts just like any other day with learning, playing, and making new memories. Remember, even without special activities, every day brings opportunities to discover something amazing. Have a fantastic day at school, buddy! </code></pre><h2 id="conclusion">Conclusion <a class="header-link" href="#conclusion"><svg height="22px" viewBox="0 0 24 24" width="22px" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M0 0h24v24H0z" fill="none"/><path d="M3.9 12c0-1.71 1.39-3.1 3.1-3.1h4V7H7c-2.76 0-5 2.24-5 5s2.24 5 5 5h4v-1.9H7c-1.71 0-3.1-1.39-3.1-3.1zM8 13h8v-2H8v2zm9-6h-4v1.9h4c1.71 0 3.1 1.39 3.1 3.1s-1.39 3.1-3.1 3.1h-4V17h4c2.76 0 5-2.24 5-5s-2.24-5-5-5z"/></svg></a></h2><p>This was a fun little project to work on, and it&rsquo;s a great example of how you can use GenAI in your smart home to make things a little more interesting.</p> <p>I&rsquo;ve had this running for a few days now (it was running in the background to test generation for a bit before I did the TTS and deprecated the original one) and the first time it ran I heard a call from my kids of &ldquo;Dad, the house said something different today!&rdquo; which is either a good sign, or a sign that Pavlov&rsquo;s bell has been replaced with a new one ü§£.</p> <p>There&rsquo;s still a few tweaks I need to do in the context around the message, for example, it will sometimes return emojis which the TTS service then reads out (we had &ldquo;sparkle smiley face&rdquo; the other day), but that&rsquo;s all part of the fun of working with GenAI.</p> <p>It was also funny when we had school sport, as we use an acronym to refer to it, but that acronym the model doesn&rsquo;t know about, so it made something up for it with&hellip; less that helpful results!</p> <p>My next plan is to plug this into the automations that announce when our various appliances have finished the cycles (see <a href="https://www.aaron-powell.com/posts/2022-08-18-building-a-smart-home---part-3-smart-appliances/">Part 3</a> of this series on how I did that), so that we can get something <em>better</em> than &ldquo;The washing machine has finished&rdquo; ü§£.</p>

item.content:encoded: <p>Where I live, we have three bins that we can put out, depending on the week, red for household rubbish, yellow for mixed recycling and green for garden waste. The red bin goes out each week, but the yellow and green alternate every other week, so you need to know which one it is that week and like a lot of people, I never know which week it is, so I sneakily wait until my neighbours put their bins out and then I put mine out, following their colour choices!</p> <p>But really, this is the kind of quality-of-life improvement that I should be able to solve with a smart home, so I decided to add it.</p> <h2 id="getting-the-data-into-home-assistant">Getting the data into Home Assistant <a class="header-link" href="#getting-the-data-into-home-assistant"><svg height="22px" viewBox="0 0 24 24" width="22px" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M0 0h24v24H0z" fill="none"/><path d="M3.9 12c0-1.71 1.39-3.1 3.1-3.1h4V7H7c-2.76 0-5 2.24-5 5s2.24 5 5 5h4v-1.9H7c-1.71 0-3.1-1.39-3.1-3.1zM8 13h8v-2H8v2zm9-6h-4v1.9h4c1.71 0 3.1 1.39 3.1 3.1s-1.39 3.1-3.1 3.1h-4V17h4c2.76 0 5-2.24 5-5s-2.24-5-5-5z"/></svg></a></h2><p>The first step is to get the data into Home Assistant.
